"**I Don 't Want to Miss a Thing**" is a [power ballad](/wiki/Power_ballad
"Power ballad")[2] performed by American [hard rock](/wiki/Hard_rock "Hard
rock") band [Aerosmith](/wiki/Aerosmith "Aerosmith") for the 1998 film
_[Armageddon](/wiki/Armageddon_\(1998_film\) "Armageddon \(1998 film\)")_
which [Steven Tyler](/wiki/Steven_Tyler "Steven Tyler")'s daughter [Liv
Tyler](/wiki/Liv_Tyler "Liv Tyler") starred in. Written by [Diane
Warren](/wiki/Diane_Warren "Diane Warren"), the song debuted at number one on
the U.S. [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")
(the first #1 for the band after 28 years together). It is one of three songs
performed by the band for the film, the other two being "[What Kind of Love
Are You On](/wiki/What_Kind_of_Love_Are_You_On "What Kind of Love Are You
On")" and "[Sweet Emotion](/wiki/Sweet_Emotion "Sweet Emotion")". The song
stayed at number one for four weeks from September 5 to 26, 1998. The song
also stayed at number 1 for several weeks in several other countries. It sold
over a million copies in the UK and reached number four on the [UK Singles
Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart").[3]

##
Inspiration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Don%27t_Want_to_Miss_a_Thing&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Inspiration")]

In 1997, Diane Warren was watching [Barbara Walters](/wiki/Barbara_Walters
"Barbara Walters") interview [James Brolin](/wiki/James_Brolin "James Brolin")
and [Barbra Streisand](/wiki/Barbra_Streisand "Barbra Streisand"). Brolin said
he missed Streisand when they were asleep, and Warren wrote down the words "I
don't want to miss a thing", before there was even a song.[4]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Don%27t_Want_to_Miss_a_Thing&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Reception")]

"When I first heard it," recalled drummer [Joey Kramer](/wiki/Joey_Kramer
"Joey Kramer"), "it was just a demo with piano and singing. It was difficult
to imagine what kind of touch Aerosmith could put on it and make it our own…
As soon as we began playing it as a band, then it instantly became an
Aerosmith song."[5]

This song was Aerosmith's biggest hit, debuting at number 1 on the U.S.
[Billboard Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"), where it
stayed for four weeks in September, and reaching number 1 around the world,
including Australia, the Philippines, Germany, Ireland, Austria, Norway,
Italy, the Netherlands, and Switzerland.

The chorus is reminiscent of an earlier song [Diane Warren](/wiki/Diane_Warren
"Diane Warren") that cowrote: "[Just Like Jesse
James](/wiki/Just_Like_Jesse_James "Just Like Jesse James")", on
[Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher")'s 1989 album _[Heart of
Stone](/wiki/Heart_of_Stone_\(Cher_album\) "Heart of Stone \(Cher album\)")_.

The song helped introduce Aerosmith to a new generation[6] and remains a slow
dance staple.[7]

It was one of many songs written by Warren in that period. The original
version was a collaboration between Chicago musician Phil Kosch of [Treaty of
Paris](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(band\) "Treaty of Paris \(band\)") and [Super
Happy Fun Club](/wiki/The_Super_Happy_Fun_Club "The Super Happy Fun Club"),
and nephew of chart topping writer [Lou Bega](/wiki/Lou_Bega "Lou Bega"). Bega
introduced the two and they penned the initial track, but ultimately Kosch was
uncredited.

The song was nominated for both an [Academy Award for Best Original
Song](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Song "Academy Award for Best
Original Song") and a [Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Original
Song](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Original_Song "Golden Raspberry
Award for Worst Original Song").

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Don%27t_Want_to_Miss_a_Thing&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Music video")]

The music video for this song was shot at the [Minneapolis
Armory](/wiki/Minneapolis_Armory "Minneapolis Armory") in 1998 and was
directed by [Francis Lawrence](/wiki/Francis_Lawrence "Francis Lawrence").[8]
It features the band playing the song intertwined with scenes from the film
_[Armageddon](/wiki/Armageddon_\(1998_film\) "Armageddon \(1998 film\)")_. It
features an appearance by [Steven Tyler](/wiki/Steven_Tyler "Steven Tyler")'s
daughter [Liv](/wiki/Liv_Tyler "Liv Tyler"), who plays Grace Stamper in the
film. Steven Tyler injured his knee the day before the shoot, so they used a
lot of close-ups because his movement was limited.

The video begins with shots of the moon in orbit and several asteroids passing
by safely and then a view of [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth") before zooming in to
show Steven Tyler singing. The shots interchange between the band and [Mission
Control](/wiki/Mission_Control "Mission Control") viewing the band singing via
their monitors. As the video progresses it reveals that the band is playing in
front of what appears to be the fictional [Space Shuttle](/wiki/Space_Shuttle
"Space Shuttle") _Freedom_. Along with Aerosmith, a full hand orchestra plays
in sync with the melody. Then smoke surrounds the orchestra and the members of
Aerosmith as _Freedom_ takes off from the launch pad. Finally, the screen goes
out as a tearful Grace touches one of the monitors to reach out to her father
(real life father Steven Tyler in the video; on-screen father Harry Stamper,
played by [Bruce Willis](/wiki/Bruce_Willis "Bruce Willis"), in the film).

The video was highly successful and greatly contributed to the song's success,
receiving heavy airplay on MTV and went on to become the second most popular
video of 1998, only behind Brandy and Monica's "[The Boy is
Mine](/wiki/The_Boy_Is_Mine_\(song\) "The Boy Is Mine \(song\)")". It also won
awards for [MTV Video Music Award for Best Video from a
Film](/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Award_for_Best_Video_from_a_Film "MTV Video Music
Award for Best Video from a Film"), and Best Video at [Boston Music
Awards](/wiki/Boston_Music_Awards "Boston Music Awards").

In late 1998, [country music](/wiki/Country_music "Country music") artist
[Mark Chesnutt](/wiki/Mark_Chesnutt "Mark Chesnutt") recorded a [cover
version](/wiki/Cover_version "Cover version") of the song. His rendition is
the first single and title track from his [1999 album of the same
name](/wiki/I_Don%27t_Want_to_Miss_a_Thing_\(album\) "I Don't Want to Miss a
Thing \(album\)").[53] Chesnutt's cover spent two weeks at number one on the
US _Billboard_ Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [Hot Country
Songs](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country Songs")) charts in early 1999, and
is the last of his eight number ones on that chart. It is also the first of
only two singles in his career to reach the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"), where it peaked at number
17 in early 1999.

## Other
appearances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Don%27t_Want_to_Miss_a_Thing&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Other appearances")]

  * The song features in the 2007 comedy film [Blades of Glory](/wiki/Blades_of_Glory "Blades of Glory") as the backing track to one of the skating routines performed by Will Ferrell and Jon Heder's characters.
  * In 2011 [Michael Guy Bowman](/w/index.php?title=Michael_Guy_Bowman&action=edit&redlink=1 "Michael Guy Bowman \(page does not exist\)") covered the song for the webcomic _[Homestuck](/wiki/Homestuck "Homestuck")_.[60] It appeared in a flash animation on the webcomic in June 2012.[61] The song was released on _Homestuck Vol. 6: Heir Transparent_ in January 2011.[62]
  * The song is featured in the 2013 video game _[Saints Row IV](/wiki/Saints_Row_IV "Saints Row IV")_.
  * In 2013 another country version of the song was released, this time by [Derek Ryan](/wiki/Derek_Ryan_\(singer\) "Derek Ryan \(singer\)").
  * In 2014 Maltese child singer [Veronica Rotin](/wiki/Veronica_Rotin "Veronica Rotin") covered the song on her debut album, [_Veronica Rotin_](/wiki/Veronica_rotin_\(album\) "Veronica rotin \(album\)").[63]
  * In 2014, as part of their album, _Just The Tip..._ , [comedy](/wiki/Comedy_music "Comedy music") [rock](/wiki/Rock_music "Rock music") [lounge](/wiki/Lounge_music "Lounge music") act [The Lounge Kittens](/wiki/The_Lounge_Kittens "The Lounge Kittens") covered the song.
  * [AT&T](/wiki/AT%26T "AT&T")/[DirecTV](/wiki/DirecTV "DirecTV") introduced a series of advertisements for the [2017 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament](/wiki/2017_NCAA_Division_I_Men%27s_Basketball_Tournament "2017 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament") featuring [CBS Sports](/wiki/CBS_Sports "CBS Sports") personality [Greg Gumbel](/wiki/Greg_Gumbel "Greg Gumbel") and comedian [Dan Finnerty](/wiki/Dan_Finnerty "Dan Finnerty"), the latter performing the song with lyrics tailored to the scene (generally people at work while March Madness games are occurring).[64]
